titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James Kirkup Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 30, 2019 at 03:03

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The James Kirkup Papers includes correspondence, writings, photographs, audiovisual material, personal documents and memorabilia that document the life and work of British author James Kirkup.The papers span his writing career, from early school papers to printouts of digital books published in the 2000s, and include documentation of the diverse genres of Kirkup's research and writing. The papers document not only Kirkup's life and work, but also pacifism as a theme in literature, twentieth-century gay life, émigré life in Japan, 20th century literature and poetry (especially haiku), and Kirkup's family history. Prominent correspondents include Akiko Takemoto and Muriel Metcalfe.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English and Japanese. Some material in French.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from James Kirkup and from Hawthorn Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 1994-2009.
Printouts of virtual books: gift of Brindin Press, 2003.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 177-178 (audiovisual material): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The James Kirkup Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James Kirkup Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection includes materials previously identified by the following call numbers: Uncat MS Vault 714, Uncat MS Vault 748, Uncat MS Vault 821, Uncat MSS 519, Uncat MSS 556, Uncat MSS 872, Uncat MSS 948, and Uncat MSS 1220.

Collection are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit. This collection received a basic level of processing in 2010-2011, including rehousing and minimal organization. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have been merged and organized as a whole.

As a rule, descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Other material by or relating to James Kirkup, including letters to Akiko Takemoto, can be found by searching Orbis (Yale's Online Catalog).
Related material can be found in the James Kirkup Collection in South Shields, cataloged at http://www.thejameskirkupcollection.co.uk/collection.html.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into seven series: I. Correspondence, 1937-2007. II. Writings, 1938-2007. III. Personal Papers and Memorabilia, circa 1920-1997. IV. Audiovisual Material, 1993-2002. V. Visual Material, circa 1890-2000s. VI. Printed Material, 1930s-2000s. VII. Manuscript Material Removed from Books, 1960s-2000s.

bioghist.head: James Kirkup, 1918-2009
bioghist.p: James Kirkup, prolific author and translator, produced hundreds of works of poetry, autobiography, drama, travel memoir, translation and obituary. Kirkup occasionally used pen names, including James Falconer, Jun Honda, Andrew James, Taeko Kawai, Felix Liston, Edward Raeburn, and Ivy B. Summerforest.Kirkup was born April 23, 1918 in South Shields, England, lived much of his life in Japan, and died May 10, 2009 in Andorra.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The James Kirkup Papers includes correspondence, writings, photographs, audiovisual material, personal documents and memorabilia that document the life and work of British author James Kirkup. The papers span his writing career, from early school papers to digital books published in the 2000s, and include documentation of the diverse genres of Kirkup's research and writing: autobiography, poetry, travel writing, obituaries, novels, dramatic works, and translations. The papers document not only Kirkup's life and work, but also pacifism as a theme in literature, twentieth-century gay life, émigré life in Japan, twentieth-century literature and poetry (especially haiku), and Kirkup's family history. Prominent correspondents include Akiko Takemoto and Muriel Metcalfe.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by correspondent. Unsorted general correspondence from the 1990s and 2000s, arranged roughly by year, is filed at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence (Series I), with dates ranging from the 1930s to the 2000s, is incoming unless otherwise indicated in the folder notes. Material in this series is chiefly professional in nature but also includes substantial files of correspondence with close friends such as Akiko Takemoto and Muriel Metcalfe. These files delve into both literary and personal topics, including the translation of poetry. Muriel Metcalfe's correspondence (filed under Sonia Lawson) includes drawings by her and by Fred Lawson. Other correspondents include publishers, translators, and fellow authors, including authors whose works Kirkup translated.
Some correspondence related to a particular work is filed in Writings (Series II).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into nine subseries: Poetry; Works of Prose; Translations by James Kirkup; Drama, Opera, and Music; Obituaries by James Kirkup; Notebooks; Reviews; Unidentified and Unsorted Writings; and Writings of Others. Unsorted writings are also filed at the end of each subseries listing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings (Series II) include drafts and/or proofs of many of Kirkup's writings and translations, spanning diverse genres: autobiography, poetry, travel writing, obituaries, novels, and dramatic works. Also included are notebooks containing drafts of poems and travel diaries. In addition to drafts and proofs, some files include correspondence, photographs or ephemera related to the research and publication of the work.
Some works are authored under one of Kirkup's many pen names, including James Falconer, Jun Honda, Andrew James, Taeko Kawai, Felix Liston, Edward Raeburn, and Ivy B. Summerforest.

Of particular interest are the "Blasphemy Files" containing material related to Kirkup's interest in this topic, which stems from the 1976 publication of Kirkup's poem "The Love that Dares to Speak Its Name" in Gay News and the resulting trial and conviction of editor Denis Lemon. These files include correspondence, clippings and research material related to blasphemy, particularly in England.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Poetry is organized under two headings: Titled Works and Untitled Works.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are grouped together by type of material but are otherwise unarranged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal Papers and Memorabilia (Series III) consists of files related to Kirkup's family history, certificates, awards and other objects of memorabilia, financial documents and educational records.

Wooden sign reading, "All the world's a little queer except thee and me, and even thee's a little queer."
Personal and school documents, including a hymn book
Documents and correspondence related to pacifist and socialist organizations
Documents relating to travel in Russia
School Certification Papers and other University Documents
Metal box engraved with a scene of a boat

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audiovisual material in Series IV is restricted pending reformatting. Reference copies may be requested. Contact Access Services for further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Audiovisual material (Series IV) consists of recordings of James Kirkup reading his poetry, video tapes about or relating to James Kirkup, and two unidentified video recordings in Japanese.

did.unittitle: Audio tapes of Kirkup reading his works
Audio tapes of Kirkup reading his works
Audio tape, lecture by James Kirkup, "where Takemoto-san was present"
Audio tape, Kirkup reading Shakespeare's Macbeth
Audio tape: "Unwritten Law" by Rib Davis, Programme 1, A Case of Blasphemous Obscenity
James Kirkup reading at Brighton with et cetera poets

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Nitrate and/or acetate negatives are stored in Restricted Fragile and may be consulted only with permission of the appropriate curator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Photographs and Other Visual Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Visual Material (Series V) consists of photographs, drawings, paintings, and collages. Photographs, which include some duplicates and negatives in addition to original prints, consist of snapshots and portraits of James Kirkup (from boyhood to adulthood), family photographs, and other photographs that Kirkup collected for his publications.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs are arranged roughly by date. Since most photographs are undated, the archivist assigned approximate dates by decade.

did.unittitle: Views of a rural scene in England (South Shields?)

James Kirkup in Japan, including negatives

Black and white duplicate prints of school photographs

Painting by James Kirkup: Clowance Wood, Horse Downs
Pencil sketches: of a woman lying down with a flute, and of a figure swimming

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Clippings and ephemera are arranged roughly chronologically. Posters and broadsides are listed at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed material (Series VI) consists of clippings, ephemera, and posters. Clippings include works by and about James Kirkup. Ephemera includes theater programs. Posters feature poems by Kirkup and others, or promote plays Kirkup wrote or translated.

did.unittitle: Ephemera: Poetry Fair at Toganji Temple in Nagoya
Clippings and ephemera related to AIDS
Clippings related to World War I

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript Material Removed From Books (Series VII) consists of correspondence, notes and ephemera removed from books that were transferred to Printed Acquisitions to be cataloged. The correspondence in this series relates chiefly to the accompanying books.
